title: 104_hr2511
content: The Act titled "Anticounterfeiting Consumer Protection Act of 1995" addresses counterfeiting as racketeering under various sections of the United States Code, including trafficking in counterfeit goods and criminal infringement of copyright. It also extends to computer programs, documentation, and packaging. Section 2318 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include computer program-related items. Section 2320 of title 18, United States Code is amended to require the Attorney General to report to Congress on investigations and cases related to trafficking in counterfeit goods. The Attorney General must report to Congress on cases involving counterfeit goods, including referrals from different agencies, outcomes of prosecutions under specific sections of title 18. SEC. 5. SEIZURE OF COUNTERFEIT GOODS. Amends the Lanham Act to allow courts to order the seizure of vehicles used in connection with violations. Service of the order can be done by federal or state law enforcement officers. SEC. 6. DISPOSITION OF MERCHANDISE BEARING COUNTERFEIT AMERICAN TRADEMARK AND CIVIL PENALTIES. Title VI of the Lanham Act is amended to include a new section 34A, stating that any merchandise with a counterfeit mark imported into the US in violation of section 42 shall be seized and forfeited if the trademark owner does not consent. The merchandise will be destroyed unless it is safe, in which case the trademark may be obliterated with consent and the goods disposed of. The amended Lanham Act allows for the seizure and forfeiture of merchandise with counterfeit marks imported into the US without the trademark owner's consent. The merchandise can be disposed of through gift, sale at public auction, or destruction if unsafe. Anyone involved in importing such merchandise may face a civil fine. The amended Lanham Act allows for the seizure and forfeiture of merchandise with counterfeit marks imported into the US without the trademark owner's consent. A civil fine may be imposed for each seizure, with the amount determined based on the value of the merchandise if it were genuine. The fine is at the discretion of the court and is in addition to any other penalties authorized by law. SEC. 7. RECOVERY FOR VIOLATION OF RIGHTS. Section 35 of the Lanham Act is amended to allow plaintiffs in cases involving counterfeit marks to elect to receive statutory damages ranging from $500 to $100,000 per counterfeit mark per type of goods or services sold, offered for sale, or distributed. If the court finds the use of the counterfeit mark was willful, the damages can be up to $1,000,000 per counterfeit mark per type of goods or services. Section 35 of the Lanham Act is amended to allow plaintiffs in cases involving counterfeit marks to elect to receive statutory damages ranging from $500 to $100,000 per counterfeit mark per type of goods or services sold, offered for sale, or distributed, as determined by the court. SEC. 8. DISPOSITION OF EXCLUDED ARTICLES. Amends Section 603(c) of title 17, United States Code, by removing unnecessary text and clarifying the case specifics. SEC. 9. RECORDKEEPING REQUIREMENTS. Section 42 of the Lanham Act is amended to allow trademark owners to obtain information from vessel or aircraft manifests, including importer/consignee details and cargo description. The Lanham Act is amended to allow trademark owners to access information from vessel or aircraft manifests, including cargo details such as the general character, number of packages, gross weight, vessel or aircraft name, port of loading, port of discharge, and country of origin. The documentation for imported merchandise must also include information to determine if the goods bear an infringing trademark.
